title: Circuits - wire resistivity - nonideal battery emf

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students has an approximately one-meter long resistive wire, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and they wish to determine the resistivity <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math> of the wire. The wire has a uniform, circular cross section.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data the students could use to determine the resistivity of the wire material. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students has an approximately one-meter long resistive wire, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and they wish to determine the resistivity <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math> of the wire. The wire has a uniform, circular cross section.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data the students could use to determine the resistivity of the wire material. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Using the data collected in the procedure you described in part (a),

describe how the students could create a linear graph from which the resistivity of the wire material could be determined, and

describe how the resistivity could be determined from the graph.

The following day, the students are given a nonideal battery, and they wish to determine the battery’s <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math>. They do not have a voltmeter with which to measure the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> directly, but they do have two ammeters <math alttext="A sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="A sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. They are able to use the resistive wire from the experiment in part (a) to make a variable resistor, and also have a precision resistor of known, fixed resistance <math alttext="R sub 1 equals 50.0 ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math>. They construct the circuit represented by the diagram in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, in which the resistive wire has a variable resistance <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Using different settings of variable resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, the students record the readings <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> from ammeters <math alttext="A sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="A sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. The experimental results are shown in the table.
<math alttext="A sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> Reading <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> <math alttext="(in milliamps)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>mA</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="A sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> Reading <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> <math alttext="(in milliamps)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>mA</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="24.7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24.7</mn></math><math alttext="44.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>44.2</mn></math><math alttext="24.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24.4</mn></math><math alttext="86.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>86.0</mn></math><math alttext="24.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24.1</mn></math><math alttext="159" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>159</mn></math><math alttext="23.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>23.6</mn></math><math alttext="220" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>220</mn></math><math alttext="23.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>23.1</mn></math><math alttext="329" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>329</mn></math><math alttext="R sub 1 equals 50.0 ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math>
(c)

i. Indicate what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for the battery’s <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>emf</mtext></math> <math alttext="uppercase script E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>.

Horizontal axis: __________          Vertical axis: __________
Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.

(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii) and, if needed, the resistance value of <math alttext="R sub 1 equals 50.0 ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math>, calculate an experimental value for the battery’s <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>emf</mtext></math> <math alttext="uppercase script E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
